          ABSTRACT

          ABSTRACT

          Providing input for the selection of objects in virtual, augmented, and mixed-mode reality can be done with hand-held controllers or hand gestures depending on the complexity and precision required. Free hand gestures have the advantages of eliminating the need for a controller, not needing to see the controls on the controller, and potentially being less fatiguing. However, the designs of hand gestures for object selection have not been thoroughly evaluated for usability and performance. Eighteen participants evaluated four different ray-casting hand gestures (index thrust, index click, palm thrust, and palm click) and three snapback thresholds while selecting 2D targets of different sizes. Dependent variables were mean time to select targets, number of selections not completed, number of incorrect targets selected, and subjective preference. The index thrust and index click gestures were preferred by subjects and had faster mean selection times and lower number of incorrect target selections. There were no significant differences between snapback thresholds on productivity, error, or preference. Overall, the index thrust and index click gestures were associated with greater user confidence, particularly with smaller targets.

          1. Introduction

          Virtual, augmented, and mixed-mode reality (VR, AR, MMR) have boundless applications ranging from recreational uses, such as gaming, to professional applications, such as product design and training. Typically, human input to these systems is via hand-held controllers. The controllers are usually designed for each hand with features similar to game controllers. However, control buttons may be difficult or impossible to see and use, especially in VR. Additionally, prolonged holding and use of controllers may lead to hand or shoulder fatigue. Free hand gestures provide an alternative form of input, and, if designed properly, may improve the usability and performance of selection tasks. For example, one study found that for free hand gestures, recognition rates of 90% or better could be achieved while for mouse gestures recognition rates ranged from 70% for complex gestures to 100% for simple gestures (Hong, Turk, & Huang, 2000). Alkamade, Verbeek, and Lukosch (2017) found that when manipulating objects in 3D, there was little difference in throughput or preference between the use of free hand gestures while in VR compared to using a mouse and screen.

          The design of hand gestures has been studied for a variety of computer tasks, including pointing at and selecting objects (Bacim, Kopper, & Bowman, 2013; Argelaguet & Andujar, 2013; Bordegoni, 1994; Pereira, Wachs, Park, & Rempel, 2015; Rautaray & Agrawal, 2012; Vogel & Balakrishnan, 2005; Wright, Lin, O’Neill, Cosker, & Johnson, 2011). Critical factors for usability are rapid execution time and high accuracy. Both the ability of the human to recall and perform the gesture and the capability of the technology to capture and recognize the gesture are important. For the simple human–computer interaction (HCI) task of object selection, a goal would be a universal gesture language, but the details of the gesture for selection are critical and will influence throughput and fatigue. For example, good usability is dependent on the design of the hand motion used for the selection command and the specific posture or velocity related threshold. For selecting small objects, there are no studies on hand gesture designs that have good performance, are intuitive, and allow for repeated use without fatigue.

          One approach for studying gestures for object selection is to evaluate how hand gestures perform across a range of target sizes. Accuracy of target selection will be influenced by the target size, the select gesture, motor control, fatigue, and the accuracy and response time of the hand detection technology. A gesture for target selection really incorporates 2 gestures: the first is the gesture for pointing at the correct target (e.g. ray-casting), the second is a gesture for selecting the target. The two gestures must work well together for both pointing accurately at a target as well as selecting the target. If the selection gesture moves the hand it may move the cursor off the target and degrade the accuracy and usability of the selection process. However, it may be possible to reduce the effects of inadvertent hand movement during the selection gesture by filtering out hand motion that occurs during the selection gesture. One approach to filtering out inadvertent hand motion is to use a “snapback” function that uses the cursor location, a short time before the selection gesture is made, for targeting.

          The purpose of this study was to compare four different free hand gestures for pointing and selecting 2D targets on productivity, usability, preference, and comfort. The outcomes were measured for different target sizes. The four gestures studied were based on prior gesture elicitation studies. In addition, different snapback thresholds were evaluated with two hand gestures.

          2. Methods

          2.1. Study design

          In this laboratory study subjects repeatedly performed point and select tasks of different sized square 2D targets on a computer monitor while using four different predefined hand gestures. Participants were eligible if they were between the ages of 18–65 years and had no shoulder or arm injuries in the past 6 months. The University Committee of Human Research approved the study and subjects signed an informed consent form.

          2.2. Independent and dependent variables

          The independent variable was four hand gestures – the order of gestures was randomized. The gestures were evaluated on four different target sizes, but the order of testing of the target sizes was not randomized. In a follow-up study, the independent variable was snapback threshold with three levels. The snapback thresholds were randomized and were evaluated on one target size with two hand gestures.

          The objective-dependent variables were time to select a target and the number of timeouts per target size. A timeout occurred if the target was not selected within 30 s. When a timeout occurred, 30 s was recorded as the time to select the target. If an incorrect target was selected, the task continued with the same image until the correct target was selected. The time to select a target included the time selecting an incorrect target.

          The subjective-dependent variables were collected using a questionnaire after all gestures were completed for a target size and included user ratings of control, shoulder fatigue, hand-arm fatigue, and motion sickness using a Likert scale and a preference ranking of gestures. At the end of the four-gesture experiment, participants completed a questionnaire that asked if any of the target sizes were too small to select and if there were any gestures they did not like.

          2.3. Four ray-casting gestures evaluated for 2D object selection

          The four gestures selected for evaluation (Figure 1) were based on prior gesture elicitation studies and reviews (Bacim et al. 2013; Argelaguet & Andujar, 2013; Pereira et al., 2015; Vogel & Balakrishnan, 2005; Wright et al., 2011). The Pereira study (2015) found that the most preferred gesture for object selection was pointing with the index finger and thrusting the finger forward to click. Vogel and Balakrishnan (2005) recommended the index finger or palm for pointing and tapping the thumb to the side of index finger to click.

          Figure 1. The four gestures evaluated for ray-casting and object selections.

          The four gestures (Figure 1) were (1) index finger pointing at object and select triggered by forward thrust of hand (index thrust); (2) index finger pointing at object and select triggered by thumb tap on side of middle finger (index click); (3) open hand with palm pointing at object and select triggered by forward thrust of hand (palm thrust); and (4) slightly closed hand with palm pointing at object and select triggered with thumb tap against tip of any of the fingers (palm click). For index pointing, the axis of the proximal phalanx was used for ray casting. For palm pointing a vector normal to the center of the palm was used for ray casting.

          The user made the selection gesture, e.g. thrust or click, when the cursor was on the target. Selection for the forward thrust gesture occurred when the forward velocity of the proximal phalanx or the palm center was greater than 160 mm/s (value selected based on pilot studies). Selection for the click gesture was based on distance between the tip of the thumb and other finger landmarks. For the palm click gesture, the distances between the thumb tip and the tips of the four other fingers were tracked and selection occurred if any of the four distances were less than approximately 2.75 mm (distance based on pilot studies). The index click selection occurred if the distance between the thumb tip and either the center of the middle phalanx or the center of the proximal phalanx of the third digit (middle finger) was less than approximately 2.75 mm. The exact trigger distance was based on hand size (i.e. 0.2 times the hand width as measured by the Leap Motion device). A debounce feature was programmed for the selection command so that participants could not maintain a continuous selection posture.

          2.4. Snapback feature

          The purpose of the snapback feature was to correct for inadvertent hand motion that might occur during the selection gesture. During either the thrust or click selection gesture, the position of the ray cast by the index finger or the palm could change, and, if so, the cursor could be moved off the target and lead to an unintended selection error.

          The snapback function scanned backward in time, from the time of target select, to identify the frames where the hand posture was relatively stable. The concept was that if there was a fast hand movement, just before selection, the frames were examined backward in time (up to 174 ms; 20 Leap Motion frames), until stable frames were identified. Then the cursor was moved to where it was during the stable frames. On the other hand, if there was a slow selection movement, i.e. slow movement of the thumb toward the fingertips or a slow thrust of the hand toward the screen, then there was no snapback correction.

          The snapback correction first involved normalizing the selection gesture to a 0–1 selection score (thrust velocity: 0 = 0 and 1 = 200 mm/s; click distance normalized value = [{hand width-distance}/hand width]). The snapback thresholds tested were 0.1 (greater snapback), 0.35 (minimal snapback), and 1 (no snapback).

          After a selection occurred, the selection score was compared to the prior frame selection score. If the difference was greater than the snapback threshold, then the current cursor position was replaced with the prior frame cursor position. This was repeated with the next prior frame until the difference in selection scores was lower than the snapback threshold or until 20 frames were reviewed. The end result was that the cursor position at the time of selection was replaced with an earlier cursor position. In this way, the position of the cursor was “snapped back” to a position when the slope of the selection score was lower than the snapback threshold.

          2.5. Workstation and equipment

          The task was programmed in the Unity game engine (5.3) using C# and utilized the Leap Motion controller (v2.0 software) to track the participant’s hand postures. The task ran on a Windows 10 computer with a 510 mm monitor (HP L2045w; 1680 × 1050 native resolution; pixel pitch 0.26 mm). The chair height was adjusted so that the participant’s knees were at approximately 90 degrees with feet flat on the floor. With the subject reclining against the seat back the chair was moved as close to the desk as possible and the desk surface was adjusted to 25 mm below the participant’s resting elbow height. The top of the monitor was aligned to the height of the subject’s nose. The leap motion controller was positioned to the left of the monitor, pointing toward the right, and aligned with the middle of the monitor height (Figure 2). The location was selected to achieve the best fidelity for tracking the right hand based on pilot studies. Participants were required to use their right hand for gesturing and were not allowed to rest their arm on any surface during the experiment.

          2.6. Targets and target size

          For each of the four different target sizes, a 5 × 5 grid of 25 black squares was displayed in 2D on the screen. The width and height of the squares, from large to small, were: 12.8, 5.1, 2.5, and 1.3 mm (see Figure 3 for large and small target size). For each task a target square was randomly selected and displayed in yellow. As soon as the subject successfully selected the target square, a new target square was randomly selected and turned yellow. The cursor on the screen, controlled by ray casting, was a 4 mm diameter blue circle with a red dot in the center.

          Other studies have used a Fitt’s law like test (e.g. ISO 9241-9) to measure throughput for pointing tasks (MacKenzie 2001). These tests involve predictable target locations and essentially measure rapid, repeated motor control. Our goal was to use a test that was closer to real world tasks (e.g. clicking on tiles, clicking on windows, menu selection). Selecting a randomized target located in 2D space increases cognitive, visual, and motor demands compared to the very repeated, almost robotic, back-and-forth movements of the Fitt’s test. The task used is similar to the 8 × 6 and 12 × 16 target grids used by Looser, Billinghurst, Grasset, and Cockburn (2007) or the random arrangement of 17 objects used by Argelaguet et al. (2009).

          2.7. Study 1: Four different hand gestures

          Participants progressed from the largest to the smallest target size and within each target size used each of the four hand gestures. Within target size the order of the hand gestures was randomized. Participants practiced the gestures with the largest target size before beginning data collection. During data collection for a target size, participants selected 26 targets using each hand gesture. The small target size was difficult to select; therefore, participants were only required to select 13 targets. There was a 10 min rest break between each gesture. No snapback was used during this study.

          2.8. Study 2: Three different snapback parameters

          Participants tested three different snapback thresholds, 0.1 (greater snapback), 0.35 (minimal snapback), and 1 (no snapback), with 2.5 mm targets and two different gestures. Within each gesture the order of presentation of snapback thresholds was randomized. The index/thrust gesture was tested first followed by the palm/click gesture. Subjects completed the usability and preference questionnaire for the snapback threshold after the three thresholds were completed within a gesture.

          2.9. Statistical analysis

          Differences in objective measures between test conditions were evaluated using repeated measures ANOVA, and, if significant, follow-up pair-wise comparisons were performed using the Tukey test to adjust for multiple comparisons. For usability and preference measures, the overall p-values were estimated using the Skillings–Mack test, and if significant, pair-wise comparisons were performed using an empirical p-value with Bonferroni adjustment for multiple comparisons.

          3. Results

          Of the 18 participants, 6 were female; the average height was 68.3 inches. One subject was left-handed but performed the gestures with the right hand. Six participants had greater than 2 hr/week of gaming experience, four participants had up to 2 hr/week of gaming experience, and eight participants had no gaming experience. Eleven participants had greater than 10 hr/week of experience with a smartphone or tablet, six had up to 10 hr/week, and one had no experience. Only one subject experienced motion sickness and there were no differences in motion sickness ratings between gestures.

          The results for the different gestures are summarized, from the largest to smallest target sizes, in Tables 1–4. Across target sizes, there was a preference for the index/click and index/thrust gestures. These two gestures tended to be associated with the least fatigue and best ratings for control. Performance varied by target size. For the large target (12.8 mm), the fastest times to complete the task were for the index/thrust and palm/thrust (Table 1). For the smallest target (1.3 mm), the fastest times were for index/click (Table 4).

          Twelve of the 18 participants reported that the 1.3 mm target was too small to readily select and 6 participants noted that the 2.5 mm target was also too small. Nine of the participants reported that they did not like the palm/thrust gesture and six did not like the palm/click gesture.

          There were few significant differences between snapback thresholds on selection time and subjective measures (Tables 5 & 6). For the index/thrust gesture, there were no significant differences in selection time or other outcomes. For the palm/click gesture, the lowest threshold (0.1) was associated with a significantly longer time to complete the task than the other thresholds. Also for the palm/click gesture, the middle snapback threshold (0.35) was associated with less shoulder and hand/arm fatigue then the other two thresholds.

          4. Discussion

          This study of ray-casting hand gestures for selecting objects found differences in preference, productivity, and usability for the component gestures for pointing and selection. For example, the time to successfully select an object was influenced more by the selection component gesture than the pointing component gesture. For pointing, the index pointing gesture was preferred over the palm pointing gesture and was associated with better control and less fatigue. For selection, the thrust gesture was associated with faster selection time for large targets while the click gesture performance was better for the smaller targets. For both the index and palm-pointing gestures, there was no significant difference in preference between the click or thrust gesture for selection. The snapback feature provided no advantages on control, preference, or throughput.

          Other approaches to gesture recognition have used the Kinect device and a skeleton-tracking model identifying multiple points on the users hand and body to detect gestures. One method included a compensation to correct for self-occlusion, e.g. one body part preventing the detection of another (Kim, Kim, & Lee, 2014). Our method of positioning the camera to the side and using points on the hand to identify gestures did not require full skeletal tracking and self-occlusion was not a problem.

          Some participants reported that with the palm gesture the hand would sometimes obstruct their view of the target and they would have to move their head to the side in order to see the target. This may have decreased throughput and increased fatigue. The preference of the index gesture may have been due to the visual occlusion associated with the palm gesture.

          For pointing, the index gesture may have also been preferred due to hand ergonomics. With the index gesture, the hand and forearm are aligned and the wrist is usually in a neutral posture. With the palm gesture, the wrist is in extension, a posture which can be fatiguing. Professional sign language interpreters report that the extended wrist – open palm gesture was one of the more uncomfortable gestures that they use (Nielsen, Störring, Moeslund, & Granum, 2003; Rempel, Camilleri, & Lee, 2014). In a study of subjects performing AR tasks using hand gestures, pointing with the index finger was one of the preferred gestures, while the open palm gesture with wrist extension was not (Billinghurst, Piumsomboon, & Bai, 2014). An advantage of the open palm gesture is the ease of gesture identification by the current technology – self occlusion is less of a problem. In fact, the palm open/fingers extended gesture is preconfigured into some gesture capture software. A study of surgeons using gestures to interact with a computer to maintain a sterile environment (Pauchot et al., 2015) used the open palm gestures but with the wrist in a neutral posture and the palm pointing down toward the floor. Objects selection was performed with finger abduction (spreading of the fingers). The study used radial/ulnar deviation to perform left and right ray casting which may be limiting given the smaller wrist range of motion in radial/ulnar deviation compared to flexion/extension.

          The preferred selection gesture, while pointing with the index finger, was the thrust gesture for large targets and the click gesture for smaller targets. The experiment evaluated gestures first with the large target size then progressing through to the smallest target size. This order of testing may have allowed for a learning effect with users becoming more comfortable with the click selection gesture with time.

          Overall, there were no significant differences between snapback thresholds on productivity, error or preference. However, there was a trend for shorter completion time, lower number of incorrect targets, and higher preference for more snapback (0.1) when using the index click gesture. For the palm click gesture, less shoulder and hand-arm fatigue was reported for the 0.35 snapback threshold. However, the differences were minor and were not associated with similar effects on preference or throughput. Future research should explore other thresholds or other methods for executing the snapback concept. For example, simply using the historical cursor position based on mean time to execute the selection gesture may reduce computation time and lead to better usability. Other studies have used other mathematical techniques such as the Kalman filter (Xu, 2017) or curvature-based algorithms (Shen, Ong, & Nee, 2011) to project hand position.

          Several limitations of the study should be noted. First, there was no separate penalty for participants when they selected the incorrect target. Incorrect selection just prolonged the process and therefore increased execution time. Participants may have compromised precision of target selection for speed particularly when selecting smaller targets. This solution may be effective for tasks for which there is no downside for multiple selections (e.g. first person shooter), but it would not be an effective approach for tasks for which accuracy is required for every selection. Another limitation was inconsistent fidelity of the Leap Motion tracker, which may have influenced user preference for certain gestures. During the experiment, it was sometimes necessary to reset the sensor by removing and replacing the hand from the sensor view.

          Future studies may evaluate the selection gesture thresholds (velocity or thumb distance) in more detail in order to optimize selection performance. The threshold values were selected based on pilot studies; an in-depth study may identify other threshold values that reduce error. One participant had a difficult time understanding the thrust gesture for executing the selection command and this raises a concern regarding the “naturalness” of the thrust action for selection.

          In conclusion, the hand gesture for selecting objects is a two-step process involving a gesture for pointing via ray casting followed by a gesture for selection. For this common task, it is important for the gestures to be natural and easy to remember, comfortable and non-fatiguing, and provide the precision necessary to minimize error. The study found that index pointing was the preferred gesture with better usability compared to palm pointing. For selection, the preferred gesture with better usability varied by target size with a forward thrust being preferred for larger target sizes and the click gesture preferred for smaller target sizes. There was no clear benefit for the snapback feature tested in the study. These findings may be useful for those who design hand gestures for HCI, especially in the setting of VR and AR.

          Additional information

          Author information

          Jeffrey Lin

          Jeffrey Lin was an undergraduate computer science major at the University of California at Berkeley at the time of the study and he who obtained his Bachelor of Science in 2016. He is currently working at Facebook, Inc.

          Carisa Harris-Adamson

          Carisa Harris-Adamson is Assistant Professor of Occupational and Environmental Medicine at the University of California at San Francisco. She obtained her Ph.D. from the University of California at Berkeley in 2010. Her research interests are in the design of workplace tasks and tools for improving performance and preventing fatigue.

          David Rempel

          David Rempel is Professor Emeritus in the Department of Bioengineering at the University of California at Berkeley. He obtained his Bachelors Degree in Bioengineering from the University of California at San Diego and his Medical Degree from the University of California at San Francisco in 1982.
